title: Curve compensation methods
content:
Hi all,

I’ve been using the method here:

[http://briem.ismennt.is/2/2.3.4a/2.3.4.34.curves.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016080242/http:/briem.ismennt.is/2/2.3.4a/2.3.4.34.curves.htm "http://briem.ismennt.is/2/2.3.4a/2.3.4.34.curves.htm")

to adjust the shape of curves for italics fonts, which is a great help in most cases. It is stated here that this is one method of doing this and I was curious if anyone knows of any other methods to compensate the curve in Italic fonts.

Rr

 [‹ apple, pages and justification bug](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016080242/http:/typophile.com/node/37760 "Go to previous forum topic") [TypeTool and OpenType ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016080242/http:/typophile.com/node/36961 "Go to next forum topic")

comments.content:
Hey, thanks for the link.  
Found lots of other useful information there as well.

Yes, Briem’s site is the best single guide to type design I know of.

Here is some useful additional description on italics: [http://typophile.com/node/14321](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016080242/http:/typophile.com/node/14321 "http://typophile.com/node/14321")?

Generally you should be aware of the [“How To” Section](http://web.archive.org/web/20071016080242/http:/typophile.com/node/12369) of the TypoWiki, which has accumulated a lot of useful stuff.
